body.p: A political polling agency wants to take a random sample of registered voters and ask whether or not they will vote for a certain candidate. One plan is to select 400 voters, another plan is select 1,600 voters.
Which of the following is true regarding the sample proportion p̂ of "yes" responses?

input.choice: The sample proportion from the sample of 400 is more likely to be close to the true population proportion, p.
The sample proportion from sample of 1,600 is more likely to be close to the true population proportion, p.
The sample proportion in either proposal is equally likely to be close to the true population proportion, p, since the sampling is random.

response.feedback:
Incorrect. Remember that the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of p̂ is:
p ( 1 − p )
n
, which clearly decreases as the sample size increases. This means that a statistic, p̂, will have a higher probability of being closer to the true population proportion, p, with a larger sample size.

Correct. The larger the sample size, the closer we expect the sample proportion to be to the true population proportion. Intuitively, this makes sense, since the larger the sample, the more it is “like the population”. More formally, since the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the sample proportion p̂ is:
p ( 1 − p )
n
, it decreases as the sample size increases. This means that for larger sample sizes, the possible values of p̂ are less spread out and therefore more likely to be closer to their mean, which is the population proportion, p.
